panels.description:
Number of tasks in the queue for the current thread pool.

High queue indicates that requests are "waiting" in line to be executed. In best circumstances queue should be close to zero. Elasticsearch imposes limit on the queue capacity, after capacity is reached, requests in queue will be rejected.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-thread-pool.html#cat-thread-pool-query-params
panels.title: Thread pool: queue

panels.description:
Number of active threads in the current thread pool.

Active threads "working" in Elasticsearch cluster. Graph show total main threads "search" and "write" compared to currently active threads.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-thread-pool.html#cat-thread-pool-query-params
panels.title: Thread pool: active

panels.description:
Number of rejected threads in the current thread pool.

Rejected threads happen when cluster is "overloaded" usually when Elasticsearch thread pool queue capacity is reached. When cluster queue capacity is reached Elasticsearch will start rejecting requests to protect cluster from complete outage.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-thread-pool.html#cat-thread-pool-query-params
panels.title: Thread pool: rejected

panels.description:
Configured fixed number of active threads allowed in the current thread pool.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-thread-pool.html#cat-thread-pool-query-params
panels.title: Thread pool: size

panels.description:
Configured core number of active threads allowed in the current thread pool.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-thread-pool.html#cat-thread-pool-query-params
panels.title: Thread pool: core

panels.description:
Highest number of active threads in the current thread pool.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-thread-pool.html#cat-thread-pool-query-params
panels.title: Thread pool: largest

panels.description:
Number of completed tasks

Completed thread pool "tasks" is useful information about thread trends. This graph indicates current throughput of per thread type in operations per minute.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/modules-threadpool.html#scaling-thread-pool
panels.title: Thread pool: completed

panels.description:
Number of tasks in the queue for the current thread pool.

Current queue size in Elasticsearch cluster per thread type.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-thread-pool.html#cat-thread-pool-query-params
panels.title: Thread pool: queue size

panels.description:
Configured maximum number of active threads allowed in the current thread pool.

Maximum number of recorded threads per type in Elasticsearch cluster.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-thread-pool.html#cat-thread-pool-query-params
panels.title: Thread pool: max

panels.description:
Request cache hit ratio calculated by hits / (hits + miss). Cache hit ratio is expressed in percentage.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Request cache hit ratio

panels.description:
Used request cache memory in Elasticsearch cluster.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Request cache memory

panels.description:
Request cache evictions. Cluster might not have evictions if refresh interval happens frequently and/or cluster has enough memory to cache all requests before starting evicting the cache.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Request cache evictions

Request cache hit count

Request cache miss count

Used query cache memory in Elasticsearch cluster.

panels.title: Query cache memory

panels.description:
Query cache evictions. Cluster might not have evictions if refresh interval happens frequently and/or cluster has enough memory to cache all requests before starting evicting the cache.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Query cache evictions

Deleted documents in Elasticsearch cluster.

panels.title: Deleted documents

panels.description:
Total time spent performing flush operations. Flush is operation of writing data back to disk.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Flushed document flush time

panels.description:
The field data cache contains field data and global ordinals, which are both used to support aggregations on certain field types. Since these are on-heap data structures, it is important to monitor the caches use.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/master/modules-fielddata.html
panels.title: Field data size

panels.description:
Number of times index was flushed. Flush is operation of writing data back to disk.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Number of flushes

panels.description:
Total index primary shards per index in Elasticsearch cluster.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Index primaries

panels.description:
Total index replica shards per index in Elasticsearch cluster.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Index Replicas

panels.description:
Open search contexts in Elasticsearch cluster. Search context is the state that is maintained for the duration of a search operation on a shard. The more concurrent search operations you have the more search context objects are active at any one time.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Open contexts

panels.description:
Time spent in indexing operations.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html

Number of current indexing operations per second in Elasticsearch cluster.

panels.description:
Number of failed indexing operations per second in Elasticsearch cluster.

panels.title: Indexing failed documents

panels.description:
Time spent to delete documents in seconds. Deleted documents are not removed instantly. Deleted documents are deleted after cluster refresh happens on each index shard per index in Elasticsearch cluster.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Deleted document deletion time

panels.description:
Number of indexed documents per index in Elasticsearch cluster.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html

panels.description:
Number of current deletions in Elasticsearch cluster.

Total used memory for indexing operations per index in Elasticsearch cluster.

Size merged of documents per index in Elasticsearch cluster.

panels.description:
Number of total segments per index in Elasticsearch cluster.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Index segments count

panels.description:
Time spent in warmers per index. Some data in the index needs to be loaded into memory for fast access to the index. Since this loading is sometimes lazy, warmers are run just before a new segment gets published in order to ensure that following requests won't need to load this data as part of the query execution. The two main things that warmers load into memory are norms (used for scoring) and field data (used for sorting and facets/aggregations).

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Warmer time

panels.description:
Total memory used by segments per index. 
Each shard contains multiple "segments", where a segment is an inverted index. A search in a shard will search each segment in turn, then combine their results into the final results for that shard.

While you are indexing documents, Elasticsearch collects them in memory (and in the transaction log, for safety) then every second or so, writes a new small segment to disk, and "refreshes" the search.

This makes the data in the new segment visible to search (ie they are "searchable"), but the segment has not been fsync'ed to disk, so is still at risk of data loss.

Every so often, Elasticsearch will "flush", which means fsync'ing the segments, (they are now "committed") and clearing out the transaction log, which is no longer needed because we know that the new data has been written to disk.

The more segments there are, the longer each search takes. So Elasticsearch will merge a number of segments of a similar size ("tier") into a single bigger segment, through a background merge process. Once the new bigger segment is written, the old segments are dropped. This process is repeated on the bigger segments when there are too many of the same size.

Segments are immutable. When a document is updated, it actually just marks the old document as deleted, and indexes a new document. The merge process also expunges these old deleted documents.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Segments memory

panels.description:
Total memory used by version map per index. Each shard contains multiple "segments", where a segment is an inverted index. A search in a shard will search each segment in turn, then combine their results into the final results for that shard.

While you are indexing documents, Elasticsearch collects them in memory (and in the transaction log, for safety) then every second or so, writes a new small segment to disk, and "refreshes" the search.

This makes the data in the new segment visible to search (ie they are "searchable"), but the segment has not been fsync'ed to disk, so is still at risk of data loss.

Every so often, Elasticsearch will "flush", which means fsync'ing the segments, (they are now "committed") and clearing out the transaction log, which is no longer needed because we know that the new data has been written to disk.

The more segments there are, the longer each search takes. So Elasticsearch will merge a number of segments of a similar size ("tier") into a single bigger segment, through a background merge process. Once the new bigger segment is written, the old segments are dropped. This process is repeated on the bigger segments when there are too many of the same size.

Segments are immutable. When a document is updated, it actually just marks the old document as deleted, and indexes a new document. The merge process also expunges these old deleted documents.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Segments version map memory

panels.description:
Total warmer operations in second. Some data in the index needs to be loaded into memory for fast access to the index. Since this loading is sometimes lazy, warmers are run just before a new segment gets published in order to ensure that following requests won't need to load this data as part of the query execution. The two main things that warmers load into memory are norms (used for scoring) and field data (used for sorting and facets/aggregations).

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Warmer total

panels.description:
Total storage size of primaries & replicas per index in Elasticsearch cluster.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Store size

panels.description:

While you are indexing documents, Elasticsearch collects them in memory (and in the transaction log, for safety) then every second or so, writes a new small segment to disk, and "refreshes" the search.

The more segments there are, the longer each search takes. So Elasticsearch will merge a number of segments of a similar size ("tier") into a single bigger segment, through a background merge process. Once the new bigger segment is written, the old segments are dropped. This process is repeated on the bigger segments when there are too many of the same size.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Segments fixed bitset memory

panels.description:
Memory used by index writer per index. Each shard contains multiple "segments", where a segment is an inverted index. A search in a shard will search each segment in turn, then combine their results into the final results for that shard.

While you are indexing documents, Elasticsearch collects them in memory (and in the transaction log, for safety) then every second or so, writes a new small segment to disk, and "refreshes" the search.

This makes the data in the new segment visible to search (ie they are "searchable"), but the segment has not been fsync'ed to disk, so is still at risk of data loss.

Every so often, Elasticsearch will "flush", which means fsync'ing the segments, (they are now "committed") and clearing out the transaction log, which is no longer needed because we know that the new data has been written to disk.

The more segments there are, the longer each search takes. So Elasticsearch will merge a number of segments of a similar size ("tier") into a single bigger segment, through a background merge process. Once the new bigger segment is written, the old segments are dropped. This process is repeated on the bigger segments when there are too many of the same size.

Segments are immutable. When a document is updated, it actually just marks the old document as deleted, and indexes a new document. The merge process also expunges these old deleted documents.

Docs: https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/cat-indices.html
panels.title: Segments index writer memory
